graduateThesis.title: Down on the Farm: World War One and the Emergence of Literary Modernism in the American South

teaching.location: Research Writing Program, University of Illinois
highlights: Facilitator for seven sections of English composition.

teaching.location: Department of English, University of Illinois
highlights: Instructor of record for two sections of literature, including Major American Authors and Introduction to Poetry per semester.
Integrated multimedia and humanities approaches to teaching literature using film and instructional technology.

research.location: Department of English, University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign
highlights: Conducted primary source research at numerous archives, examining publication history through multiple sources.
Examined the literature of William Faulkner, Thomas Wolfe, and Tennessee Williams, exploring their publication records, construction of literary identity, and relationship with modernism.

research.location: Department of English, University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign
highlights: Assistant to Professor Robert Warren, conducting primary and secondary source research.
Organized for the “New Directions in the Study of Southern Literature: An Interdisciplinary Conference.”

publications.publication: Johnson, JM, Lolie, T., and Green, R. “Lost on the Farm: Popular Beliefs” Somebody Journal, Special Issue, Reflections on the Americas. Vol. 6. Accepted and forthcoming.
Davis, D.A. and Green, R. “Will N. Harben,” “Etheridge Knight,” and “James Wilcox” in Southern Writers: A Biographical Dictionary. Louisiana State University Press, 20xx.

presentations.title: “The Ministry of Rev. Thomas H. Jones,” South Atlantic Modern Language Association. Atlanta, GA, May 20xx.
“Shackles and Stripes: The Cinematic Representation of the Southern Chain Gain.” American Literature Association. Cambridge, Massachusetts, November 20xx.

awards.title: Campus Teaching Award based on student evaluations

professionalAffiliation.title: Southern Literary Journal
highlights: Maintain editorial correspondence with prospective contributors.
Conduct business transactions including publicity, subscriptions and advertising.

professionalAffiliation.title: University Quarterly
highlights: Review and solicit poems for possible publication.
